Award.AwardTitle: PARTICLE AND QUANTUM FIELD THEORY INVESTIGATIONS
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal covers many interrelated topics aiming to answer truly fundamental questions in theoretical physics. Among them: what is the correct gravity theory at large (cosmic) distances? What is quantum gravity? What is its energy scale? How (in)distinguishable are black holes? What is the origin of and solution to the hierarchy problem? The group consists of four theorists who work both separately and together on these fundamental questions.
Porrati intends to undertake a systematic study of general theorems on interacting high-spin particles, both massive and massless. He proposes to extend previous results on back-reaction effects of gravity to understand their effects at short and large distances. He will work with G. Dvali and G. Gabadadze to understand the dynamics of IR modified gravity as well as of standard General Relativity. Porrati will use his expertise in string theory, and his past work on the AdS/CFT duality to study simpler,
potentially soluble models of quantum gravity in lower dimension.
Gabadadze is planning to approach the cosmological constant problem, and the issue of cosmic acceleration within the paradigm of large distance modification of gravity. He will: search for brane induced gravity models that lead to an accelerated expansion.
Sirlin plans to continue his studies of several aspects of precision electroweak physics and related concepts in Quantum Field Theory, and to pursue the search of signals and bounds for new physics beyond the Standard Model. Dvali's research will focus on identifying and studying the new physics beyond the Standard Model, both in cosmology and particle physics. He is interested in how the dynamics behind the mechanism of stabilizing the weak scale will have consequences for LHC physics (such as, for example, production of mini black holes). He is also interested in theories of gravity that provide new physics at long distances, that on the one hand could explain the accelerated expansion of the Universe, and on the other can have testable experimental consequences.
The PIs are involved in working with the NYU School of education on various outreach projects. They also give popular lectures, serve as liaisons with Latin-American students and write popular science articles.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PIs obtained significant results in intercorrelated wide areas of research inhigh energy thery, spanning from precision Standard Model physics --an irreplaceable tool to evince signatures of new physics-- to cosmology and quantum gravity.

Porrati's research was conducted either alone or in collaboration with PhD students and postdocs at NYU as well as colleagues from the USA, CERN (Switzerland) , Italy, the Netherlands, and Argentina. Porrati found general no go theorems on the existence of massless particles of high spin and constructed explicitly, for the first time, interacting theories of massive high spin particles. Porrati also discovered how to realize models of slow-roll inflation favored by
recent satellite mission data, such as Planck, within the theoretical framework best suited to describe the low-energy dynamics of string theory: supergravity.


The main outcome of Dvali's work has been to put forward, together with Cesar Gomez, new ideas about the microscopic structure of black holes and other space-times. In this new picture, black holes are composites of enormous number of quantum constituents, each having a black-hole sized wavelength. In this picture, all the macroscopic properties of black holes are emergent as a result of quantum interactions of these constituents. This picture sheds a new
light on the nature of quantum gravity and of space-time in general.


In collaboration with B.A. Kniehl, Sirlin proposed a simple approach to renormalize the Cabibbo-Kobayashi-Maskawa flavor-mixing matrix that rules the charged-current interactions of the quarks.They also analyzed important aspects of the renormalization of general theories with intergeneration mixing. Sirlin derived an analytic expression for the radiative corrections to the antineutrino (neutrino) spectrum in beta-decay that is of considerable interest for reactor studies of neutrino oscillations. In collaboration with A. Ferroglia, Sirlin wrote a review article, commissioned by Revs. Mod. Phys., on the important role played by radiative corrections in precision Electroweak Physics. It covers more than 50 years, from the mid-1950's to 2012. In collaboration with A. Ferroglia, Ch. Greub and Z. Zhang, Sirlin analyzed the contributions of the W-boson propagator to the muon and tau leptonic decay rates.

Gabadadze and collaborators predicted the existence of a new state of matter that should exist in certain astrophysical objects, helium-core white dwarf stars and brown dwarf stars. Gabadadze and his collaborators have found a long-sought extension of Einstein's gravity, wherein the graviton has a mass.
